channel.title: TEDTalks (video)
channel.description: Each year, the TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) conference hosts some of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (also available in audio format) capture the most extraordinary presentations delivered from the TED stage.

channel.itunes:author: TED
channel.itunes:summary: Each year, the TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) conference hosts some of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (also available in audio format) capture the most extraordinary presentations delivered from the TED stage.
channel.feedburner:browserFriendly: Each year, TED hosts 80 of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (also available in audio format) capture the most extraordinary presentations delivered from the TED stage. Each week, we'll release a new talk to inspire, intrigue and stir the imagination. For best effect, plan to listen to at least three, start to finish. (They have a cumulative effect.) If you have a curious soul and an open mind, we think you'll be hooked...

item.title: TEDTalks : John Hardy: My green school dream - John Hardy (2010)
item.itunes:author: John Hardy
item.description: Join John Hardy on a tour of the Green School, his off-the-grid school in Bali that teaches kids how to build, garden, create (and get into college). The centerpiece of campus is the spiraling Heart of School, perhaps the world's largest freestanding bamboo building.
item.itunes:subtitle: John Hardy: My green school dream
item.itunes:summary: Join John Hardy on a tour of the Green School, his off-the-grid school in Bali that teaches kids how to build, garden, create (and get into college). The centerpiece of campus is the spiraling Heart of School, perhaps the world's largest freestanding bamboo building.

item.title: TEDTalks : Shimon Schocken's rides of hope - Shimon Schocken (2010)
item.itunes:author: Shimon Schocken
item.description: Computer science professor Shimon Schocken is also an avid mountain biker. To share the life lessons he learned while riding, he began an outdoor program with Israel's juvenile inmates and was touched by both their intense difficulties and profound successes.
item.itunes:subtitle: Shimon Schocken's rides of hope
item.itunes:summary: Computer science professor Shimon Schocken is also an avid mountain biker. To share the life lessons he learned while riding, he began an outdoor program with Israel's juvenile inmates and was touched by both their intense difficulties and profound successes.

item.title: TEDTalks : Denis Dutton: A Darwinian theory of beauty - Denis Dutton (2010)
item.itunes:author: Denis Dutton
item.description: TED collaborates with animator Andrew Park to illustrate Denis Dutton's provocative theory on beauty -- that art, music and other beautiful things, far from being simply "in the eye of the beholder," are a core part of human nature with deep evolutionary origins.
item.itunes:subtitle: Denis Dutton: A Darwinian theory of beauty
item.itunes:summary: TED collaborates with animator Andrew Park to illustrate Denis Dutton's provocative theory on beauty -- that art, music and other beautiful things, far from being simply "in the eye of the beholder," are a core part of human nature with deep evolutionary origins.

item.title: TEDTalks : Conrad Wolfram: Teaching kids real math with computers - Conrad Wolfram (2010)
item.itunes:author: Conrad Wolfram
item.description: From rockets to stock markets, many of humanity's most thrilling creations are powered by math. So why do kids lose interest in it? Conrad Wolfram says the part of math we teach -- calculation by hand -- isn't just tedious, it's mostly irrelevant to real mathematics and the real world. He presents his radical idea: teaching kids math through computer programming.
item.itunes:subtitle: Conrad Wolfram: Teaching kids real math with computers
item.itunes:summary: From rockets to stock markets, many of humanity's most thrilling creations are powered by math. So why do kids lose interest in it? Conrad Wolfram says the part of math we teach -- calculation by hand -- isn't just tedious, it's mostly irrelevant to real mathematics and the real world. He presents his radical idea: teaching kids math through computer programming.

item.title: TEDTalks : Eric Berlow: How complexity leads to simplicity - Eric Berlow (2010)
item.itunes:author: Eric Berlow
item.description: Ecologist Eric Berlow doesn't feel overwhelmed when faced with complex systems. He knows that more information can lead to a better, simpler solution. Illustrating the tips and tricks for breaking down big issues, he distills an overwhelming infographic on U.S. strategy in Afghanistan to a few elementary points.
item.itunes:subtitle: Eric Berlow: How complexity leads to simplicity
item.itunes:summary: Ecologist Eric Berlow doesn't feel overwhelmed when faced with complex systems. He knows that more information can lead to a better, simpler solution. Illustrating the tips and tricks for breaking down big issues, he distills an overwhelming infographic on U.S. strategy in Afghanistan to a few elementary points.

item.title: TEDTalks : Auret van Heerden: Making global labor fair - Auret van Heerden (2010)
item.itunes:author: Auret van Heerden
item.description: Labor activist Auret van Heerden talks about the next frontier of workers' rights -- globalized industries where no single national body can keep workers safe and protected. How can we keep our global supply chains honest? Van Heerden makes the business case for fair labor.
item.itunes:subtitle: Auret van Heerden: Making global labor fair
item.itunes:summary: Labor activist Auret van Heerden talks about the next frontier of workers' rights -- globalized industries where no single national body can keep workers safe and protected. How can we keep our global supply chains honest? Van Heerden makes the business case for fair labor.

item.title: TEDTalks : Aaron Huey: America's native prisoners of war - Aaron Huey (2010)
item.itunes:author: Aaron Huey
item.description: Aaron Huey's effort to photograph poverty in America led him to the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, where the struggle of the native Lakota people -- appalling, and largely ignored -- compelled him to refocus. Five years of work later, his haunting photos intertwine with a shocking history lesson in this bold, courageous talk from TEDxDU.
item.itunes:subtitle: Aaron Huey: America's native prisoners of war
item.itunes:summary: Aaron Huey's effort to photograph poverty in America led him to the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, where the struggle of the native Lakota people -- appalling, and largely ignored -- compelled him to refocus. Five years of work later, his haunting photos intertwine with a shocking history lesson in this bold, courageous talk from TEDxDU.

item.title: TEDTalks : Stefan Wolff: The path to ending ethnic conflicts - Stefan Wolff (2010)
item.itunes:author: Stefan Wolff
item.description: Civil wars and ethnic conflicts have brought the world incredible suffering, but Stefan Wolff's figures show that, in the last 20 years, their number has steadily decreased. He extracts critical lessons from Northern Ireland, Liberia, Timor and more to show that leadership, diplomacy and institutional design are our three most effective weapons in waging peace.
item.itunes:subtitle: Stefan Wolff: The path to ending ethnic conflicts
item.itunes:summary: Civil wars and ethnic conflicts have brought the world incredible suffering, but Stefan Wolff's figures show that, in the last 20 years, their number has steadily decreased. He extracts critical lessons from Northern Ireland, Liberia, Timor and more to show that leadership, diplomacy and institutional design are our three most effective weapons in waging peace.

item.title: TEDTalks : Emily Pilloton: Teaching design for change - Emily Pilloton (2010)
item.itunes:author: Emily Pilloton
item.description: Designer Emily Pilloton moved to rural Bertie County, in North Carolina, to engage in a bold experiment of design-led community transformation. She's teaching a design-build class called Studio H that engages high schoolers' minds and bodies while bringing smart design and new opportunities to the poorest county in the state.
item.itunes:subtitle: Emily Pilloton: Teaching design for change
item.itunes:summary: Designer Emily Pilloton moved to rural Bertie County, in North Carolina, to engage in a bold experiment of design-led community transformation. She's teaching a design-build class called Studio H that engages high schoolers' minds and bodies while bringing smart design and new opportunities to the poorest county in the state.

item.title: TEDTalks : Andrew Bird's one-man orchestra of the imagination - Andrew Bird (2010)
item.itunes:author: Andrew Bird
item.description: Musical innovator Andrew Bird winds together his trademark violin technique with xylophone, vocals and sophisticated electronic looping. Add in his uncanny ability to whistle anything, and he becomes a riveting one-man orchestra.
item.itunes:subtitle: Andrew Bird's one-man orchestra of the imagination
item.itunes:summary: Musical innovator Andrew Bird winds together his trademark violin technique with xylophone, vocals and sophisticated electronic looping. Add in his uncanny ability to whistle anything, and he becomes a riveting one-man orchestra.

item.title: TEDTalks : Gero Miesenboeck reengineers a brain - Gero Miesenboeck (2010)
item.itunes:author: Gero Miesenboeck
item.description: In the quest to map the brain, many scientists have attempted the incredibly daunting task of recording the activity of each neuron. Gero Miesenboeck works backward -- manipulating specific neurons to figure out exactly what they do, through a series of stunning experiments that reengineer the way fruit flies percieve light.
item.itunes:subtitle: Gero Miesenboeck reengineers a brain
item.itunes:summary: In the quest to map the brain, many scientists have attempted the incredibly daunting task of recording the activity of each neuron. Gero Miesenboeck works backward -- manipulating specific neurons to figure out exactly what they do, through a series of stunning experiments that reengineer the way fruit flies percieve light.

item.title: TEDTalks : Greg Stone: Saving the ocean one island at a time - Greg Stone (2010)
item.itunes:author: Greg Stone
item.description: Aboard Mission Blue, scientist Greg Stone tells the story of how he helped the Republic of Kiribati create an enormous protected area in the middle of the Pacific -- protecting fish, sealife and the island nation itself.
item.itunes:subtitle: Greg Stone: Saving the ocean one island at a time
item.itunes:summary: Aboard Mission Blue, scientist Greg Stone tells the story of how he helped the Republic of Kiribati create an enormous protected area in the middle of the Pacific -- protecting fish, sealife and the island nation itself.

item.title: TEDTalks : David Bismark: E-voting without fraud - David Bismark (2010)
item.itunes:author: David Bismark
item.description: David Bismark demos a new system for voting that contains a simple, verifiable way to prevent fraud and miscounting -- while keeping each person's vote secret.
item.itunes:subtitle: David Bismark: E-voting without fraud
item.itunes:summary: David Bismark demos a new system for voting that contains a simple, verifiable way to prevent fraud and miscounting -- while keeping each person's vote secret.

item.title: TEDTalks : Tom Chatfield: 7 ways games reward the brain - Tom Chatfield (2010)
item.itunes:author: Tom Chatfield
item.description: We're bringing gameplay into more aspects of our lives, spending countless hours -- and real money -- exploring virtual worlds for imaginary treasures. Why? As Tom Chatfield shows, games are perfectly tuned to dole out rewards that engage the brain and keep us questing for more.
item.itunes:subtitle: Tom Chatfield: 7 ways games reward the brain
item.itunes:summary: We're bringing gameplay into more aspects of our lives, spending countless hours -- and real money -- exploring virtual worlds for imaginary treasures. Why? As Tom Chatfield shows, games are perfectly tuned to dole out rewards that engage the brain and keep us questing for more.

item.title: TEDTalks : Miwa Matreyek's glorious visions - Miwa Matreyek (2010)
item.itunes:author: Miwa Matreyek
item.description: Using animation, projections and her own moving shadow, Miwa Matreyek performs a gorgeous, meditative piece about inner and outer discovery. Take a quiet 10 minutes and dive in. With music from Anna Oxygen, Mirah, Caroline Lufkin and Mileece.
item.itunes:subtitle: Miwa Matreyek's glorious visions
item.itunes:summary: Using animation, projections and her own moving shadow, Miwa Matreyek performs a gorgeous, meditative piece about inner and outer discovery. Take a quiet 10 minutes and dive in. With music from Anna Oxygen, Mirah, Caroline Lufkin and Mileece.

item.title: TEDTalks : Shimon Steinberg: Natural pest control ... using bugs! - Shimon Steinberg (2010)
item.itunes:author: Shimon Steinberg
item.description: At TEDxTelAviv, Shimon Steinberg looks at the difference between pests and bugs -- and makes the case for using good bugs to fight bad bugs, avoiding chemicals in our quest for perfect produce.
item.itunes:subtitle: Shimon Steinberg: Natural pest control ... using bugs!
item.itunes:summary: At TEDxTelAviv, Shimon Steinberg looks at the difference between pests and bugs -- and makes the case for using good bugs to fight bad bugs, avoiding chemicals in our quest for perfect produce.

item.title: TEDTalks : Barton Seaver: Sustainable seafood? Let's get smart - Barton Seaver (2010)
item.itunes:author: Barton Seaver
item.description: Chef Barton Seaver presents a modern dilemma: Seafood is one of our healthier protein options, but overfishing is desperately harming our oceans. He suggests a simple way to keep fish on the dinner table that includes every mom's favorite adage -- "Eat your vegetables!"
item.itunes:subtitle: Barton Seaver: Sustainable seafood? Let's get smart
item.itunes:summary: Chef Barton Seaver presents a modern dilemma: Seafood is one of our healthier protein options, but overfishing is desperately harming our oceans. He suggests a simple way to keep fish on the dinner table that includes every mom's favorite adage -- "Eat your vegetables!"

item.title: TEDTalks : Joseph Nye on global power shifts - Joseph Nye (2010)
item.itunes:author: Joseph Nye
item.description: Historian and diplomat Joseph Nye gives us the 30,000-foot view of the shifts in power between China and the US, and the global implications as economic, political and "soft" power shifts and moves around the globe.
item.itunes:subtitle: Joseph Nye on global power shifts
item.itunes:summary: Historian and diplomat Joseph Nye gives us the 30,000-foot view of the shifts in power between China and the US, and the global implications as economic, political and "soft" power shifts and moves around the globe.

item.title: TEDTalks : R.A. Mashelkar: Breakthrough designs for ultra-low-cost products - R.A. Mashelkar (2009)
item.itunes:author: R.A. Mashelkar
item.description: Engineer RA Mashelkar shares three stories of ultra-low-cost design from India that use bottom-up rethinking, and some clever engineering, to bring expensive products (cars, prosthetics) into the realm of the possible for everyone.
item.itunes:subtitle: R.A. Mashelkar: Breakthrough designs for ultra-low-cost products
item.itunes:summary: Engineer RA Mashelkar shares three stories of ultra-low-cost design from India that use bottom-up rethinking, and some clever engineering, to bring expensive products (cars, prosthetics) into the realm of the possible for everyone.

item.title: TEDTalks : David Byrne sings "(Nothing But) Flowers" - David Byrne / Thomas Dolby / Ethel (2010)
item.itunes:author: David Byrne / Thomas Dolby / Ethel
item.description: David Byrne sings the Talking Heads' 1988 hit, "(Nothing But) Flowers." He's accompanied by Thomas Dolby and string quartet Ethel, who made up the TED2010 house band.
item.itunes:subtitle: David Byrne sings "(Nothing But) Flowers"
item.itunes:summary: David Byrne sings the Talking Heads' 1988 hit, "(Nothing But) Flowers." He's accompanied by Thomas Dolby and string quartet Ethel, who made up the TED2010 house band.

item.title: TEDTalks : Patrick Chappatte: The power of cartoons - Patrick Chappatte (2010)
item.itunes:author: Patrick Chappatte
item.description: In a series of witty punchlines, Patrick Chappatte makes a poignant case for the power of the humble cartoon. His projects in Lebanon, West Africa and Gaza show how, in the right hands, the pencil can illuminate serious issues and bring the most unlikely people together.
item.itunes:subtitle: Patrick Chappatte: The power of cartoons
item.itunes:summary: In a series of witty punchlines, Patrick Chappatte makes a poignant case for the power of the humble cartoon. His projects in Lebanon, West Africa and Gaza show how, in the right hands, the pencil can illuminate serious issues and bring the most unlikely people together.

item.title: TEDTalks : Dianna Cohen: Tough truths about plastic pollution - Dianna Cohen (2010)
item.itunes:author: Dianna Cohen
item.description: Artist Dianna Cohen shares some tough truths about plastic pollution in the ocean and in our lives -- and some thoughts on how to free ourselves from the plastic gyre.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dianna Cohen: Tough truths about plastic pollution
item.itunes:summary: Artist Dianna Cohen shares some tough truths about plastic pollution in the ocean and in our lives -- and some thoughts on how to free ourselves from the plastic gyre.

item.title: TEDTalks : Heribert Watzke: The brain in your gut - Heribert Watzke (2010)
item.itunes:author: Heribert Watzke
item.description: Did you know you have functioning neurons in your intestines -- about a hundred million of them? Food scientist Heribert Watzke tells us about the "hidden brain" in our gut and the surprising things it makes us feel.
item.itunes:subtitle: Heribert Watzke: The brain in your gut
item.itunes:summary: Did you know you have functioning neurons in your intestines -- about a hundred million of them? Food scientist Heribert Watzke tells us about the "hidden brain" in our gut and the surprising things it makes us feel.

item.title: TEDTalks : Jessica Jackley: Poverty, money -- and love - Jessica Jackley (2010)
item.itunes:author: Jessica Jackley
item.description: What do you think of people in poverty? Maybe what Jessica Jackley once did: "they" need "our" help, in the form of a few coins in a jar. The co-founder of Kiva.org talks about how her attitude changed -- and how her work with microloans has brought new power to people who live on a few dollars a day.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jessica Jackley: Poverty, money -- and love
item.itunes:summary: What do you think of people in poverty? Maybe what Jessica Jackley once did: "they" need "our" help, in the form of a few coins in a jar. The co-founder of Kiva.org talks about how her attitude changed -- and how her work with microloans has brought new power to people who live on a few dollars a day.

item.title: TEDTalks : Ze Frank's web playroom - Ze Frank (2010)
item.itunes:author: Ze Frank
item.description: On the web, a new "Friend" may be just a click away, but true connection is harder to find and express. Ze Frank presents a medley of zany Internet toys that require deep participation -- and reward it with something more nourishing. You're invited, if you promise you'll share.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ze Frank's web playroom
item.itunes:summary: On the web, a new "Friend" may be just a click away, but true connection is harder to find and express. Ze Frank presents a medley of zany Internet toys that require deep participation -- and reward it with something more nourishing. You're invited, if you promise you'll share.

item.title: TEDTalks : Natalie Jeremijenko: The art of the eco-mindshift - Natalie Jeremijenko (2009)
item.itunes:author: Natalie Jeremijenko
item.description: Natalie Jeremijenko's unusual lab puts art to work, and addresses environmental woes by combining engineering know-how with public art and a team of volunteers. These real-life experiments include: Walking tadpoles, texting "fish," planting fire-hydrant gardens and more.
item.itunes:subtitle: Natalie Jeremijenko: The art of the eco-mindshift
item.itunes:summary: Natalie Jeremijenko's unusual lab puts art to work, and addresses environmental woes by combining engineering know-how with public art and a team of volunteers. These real-life experiments include: Walking tadpoles, texting "fish," planting fire-hydrant gardens and more.

item.title: TEDTalks : Peter Haas: Haiti's disaster of engineering - Peter Haas (2010)
item.itunes:author: Peter Haas
item.description: "Haiti was not a natural disaster," says TED Fellow Peter Haas: "It was a disaster of engineering." As the country rebuilds after January's deadly quake, are bad old building practices creating another ticking time bomb? Haas's group, AIDG, is helping Haiti's builders learn modern building and engineering practices, to assemble a strong country brick by brick.
item.itunes:subtitle: Peter Haas: Haiti's disaster of engineering
item.itunes:summary: "Haiti was not a natural disaster," says TED Fellow Peter Haas: "It was a disaster of engineering." As the country rebuilds after January's deadly quake, are bad old building practices creating another ticking time bomb? Haas's group, AIDG, is helping Haiti's builders learn modern building and engineering practices, to assemble a strong country brick by brick.

item.title: TEDTalks : Melinda French Gates: What nonprofits can learn from Coca-Cola - Melinda French Gates (2010)
item.itunes:author: Melinda French Gates
item.description: At TEDxChange, Melinda Gates makes a provocative case for nonprofits taking a cue from corporations such as Coca-Cola, whose plugged-in, global network of marketers and distributors ensures that every remote village wants -- and can get -- a Coke. Why shouldn't this work for condoms, sanitation, vaccinations too?
item.itunes:subtitle: Melinda French Gates: What nonprofits can learn from Coca-Cola
item.itunes:summary: At TEDxChange, Melinda Gates makes a provocative case for nonprofits taking a cue from corporations such as Coca-Cola, whose plugged-in, global network of marketers and distributors ensures that every remote village wants -- and can get -- a Coke. Why shouldn't this work for condoms, sanitation, vaccinations too?

item.title: TEDTalks : Stefano Mancuso: The roots of plant intelligence - Stefano Mancuso (2010)
item.itunes:author: Stefano Mancuso
item.description: Plants behave in some oddly intelligent ways: fighting predators, maximizing food opportunities ... But can we think of them as actually having a form of intelligence of their own? Italian botanist Stefano Mancuso presents intriguing evidence.
item.itunes:subtitle: Stefano Mancuso: The roots of plant intelligence
item.itunes:summary: Plants behave in some oddly intelligent ways: fighting predators, maximizing food opportunities ... But can we think of them as actually having a form of intelligence of their own? Italian botanist Stefano Mancuso presents intriguing evidence.

item.title: TEDTalks : Stacey Kramer: The best gift I ever survived - Stacey Kramer (2010)
item.itunes:author: Stacey Kramer
item.description: Stacey Kramer offers a moving, personal, 3-minute parable that shows how an unwanted experience -- frightening, traumatic, costly -- can turn out to be a priceless gift.
item.itunes:subtitle: Stacey Kramer: The best gift I ever survived
item.itunes:summary: Stacey Kramer offers a moving, personal, 3-minute parable that shows how an unwanted experience -- frightening, traumatic, costly -- can turn out to be a priceless gift.

item.title: TEDTalks : Hans Rosling: The good news of the decade? - Hans Rosling (2010)
item.itunes:author: Hans Rosling
item.description: Hans Rosling reframes 10 years of UN data with his spectacular visuals, lighting up an astonishing -- mostly unreported -- piece of front-page-worthy good news: We're winning the war against child mortality. Along the way, he debunks one flawed approach to stats that blots out such vital stories.
item.itunes:subtitle: Hans Rosling: The good news of the decade?
item.itunes:summary: Hans Rosling reframes 10 years of UN data with his spectacular visuals, lighting up an astonishing -- mostly unreported -- piece of front-page-worthy good news: We're winning the war against child mortality. Along the way, he debunks one flawed approach to stats that blots out such vital stories.

item.title: TEDTalks : Barbara Block: Tagging tuna in the deep ocean - Barbara Block (2010)
item.itunes:author: Barbara Block
item.description: Tuna are ocean athletes -- fast, far-ranging predators whose habits we're just beginning to understand. Marine biologist Barbara Block fits tuna with tracking tags (complete with transponders) that record unprecedented amounts of data about these gorgeous, threatened fish and the ocean habitats they move through.
item.itunes:subtitle: Barbara Block: Tagging tuna in the deep ocean

Marine biologist Barbara Block fits tuna with tracking tags (complete with transponders) that record unprecedented amounts of data about these gorgeous, threatened fish and the ocean habitats they move through.

item.title: TEDTalks : Tim Jackson's economic reality check - Tim Jackson (2010)
item.itunes:author: Tim Jackson
item.description: As the world faces recession, climate change, inequity and more, Tim Jackson delivers a piercing challenge to established economic principles, explaining how we might stop feeding the crises and start investing in our future.
item.itunes:subtitle: Tim Jackson's economic reality check
item.itunes:summary: As the world faces recession, climate change, inequity and more, Tim Jackson delivers a piercing challenge to established economic principles, explaining how we might stop feeding the crises and start investing in our future.

item.title: TEDTalks : Eben Bayer: Are mushrooms the new plastic? - Eben Bayer (2010)
item.itunes:author: Eben Bayer
item.description: Product designer Eben Bayer reveals his recipe for a new, fungus-based packaging material that protects fragile stuff like furniture, plasma screens -- and the environment.
item.itunes:subtitle: Eben Bayer: Are mushrooms the new plastic?
item.itunes:summary: Product designer Eben Bayer reveals his recipe for a new, fungus-based packaging material that protects fragile stuff like furniture, plasma screens -- and the environment.

item.title: TEDTalks : Mechai Viravaidya: How Mr. Condom made Thailand a better place - Mechai Viravaidya (2010)
item.itunes:author: Mechai Viravaidya
item.description: At TEDxChange, Thailand's "Mr. Condom," Mechai Viravaidya, walks us through the country's bold plan to raise its standard of living, starting in the 1970s. First step: population control. And that means a lot of frank, funny -- and very effective -- talk about condoms.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mechai Viravaidya: How Mr. Condom made Thailand a better place
item.itunes:summary: At TEDxChange, Thailand's "Mr. Condom," Mechai Viravaidya, walks us through the country's bold plan to raise its standard of living, starting in the 1970s. First step: population control. And that means a lot of frank, funny -- and very effective -- talk about condoms.

item.title: TEDTalks : Inge Missmahl brings peace to the minds of Afghanistan - Inge Missmahl (2010)
item.itunes:author: Inge Missmahl
item.description: When Jungian analyst Inge Missmahl visited Afghanistan, she saw the inner wounds of war -- widespread despair, trauma and depression. And yet, in this county of 30 million people, there were only two dozen psychiatrists. Missmahl talks about her work helping to build the country's system of psychosocial counseling, promoting both individual and, perhaps, national healing.
item.itunes:subtitle: Inge Missmahl brings peace to the minds of Afghanistan
item.itunes:summary: When Jungian analyst Inge Missmahl visited Afghanistan, she saw the inner wounds of war -- widespread despair, trauma and depression. And yet, in this county of 30 million people, there were only two dozen psychiatrists. Missmahl talks about her work helping to build the country's system of psychosocial counseling, promoting both individual and, perhaps, national healing.

item.title: TEDTalks : Sebastian Seung: I am my connectome - Sebastian Seung (2010)
item.itunes:author: Sebastian Seung
item.description: Sebastian Seung is mapping a massively ambitious new model of the brain that focuses on the connections between each neuron. He calls it our "connectome," and it's as individual as our genome -- and understanding it could open a new way to understand our brains and our minds.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sebastian Seung: I am my connectome
item.itunes:summary: Sebastian Seung is mapping a massively ambitious new model of the brain that focuses on the connections between each neuron. He calls it our "connectome," and it's as individual as our genome -- and understanding it could open a new way to understand our brains and our minds.

item.title: TEDTalks : Gary Wolf: The quantified self - Gary Wolf (2010)
item.itunes:author: Gary Wolf
item.description: At TED@Cannes, Gary Wolf gives a 5-min intro to an intriguing new pastime: using mobile apps and always-on gadgets to track and analyze your body, mood, diet, spending -- just about everything in daily life you can measure -- in gloriously geeky detail.
item.itunes:subtitle: Gary Wolf: The quantified self
item.itunes:summary: At TED@Cannes, Gary Wolf gives a 5-min intro to an intriguing new pastime: using mobile apps and always-on gadgets to track and analyze your body, mood, diet, spending -- just about everything in daily life you can measure -- in gloriously geeky detail.

item.title: TEDTalks : Julian Treasure: Shh! Sound health in 8 steps - Julian Treasure (2010)
item.itunes:author: Julian Treasure
item.description: Julian Treasure says our increasingly noisy world is gnawing away at our mental health -- even costing lives. He lays out an 8-step plan to soften this sonic assault (starting with those cheap earbuds) and restore our relationship with sound.
item.itunes:subtitle: Julian Treasure: Shh! Sound health in 8 steps
item.itunes:summary: Julian Treasure says our increasingly noisy world is gnawing away at our mental health -- even costing lives. He lays out an 8-step plan to soften this sonic assault (starting with those cheap earbuds) and restore our relationship with sound.

item.title: TEDTalks : Fabian Hemmert: The shape-shifting future of the mobile phone - Fabian Hemmert (2010)
item.itunes:author: Fabian Hemmert
item.description: At TEDxBerlin, Fabian Hemmert demos one future of the mobile phone -- a shape-shifting and weight-shifting handset that "displays" information nonvisually, offering a delightfully intuitive way to communicate.
item.itunes:subtitle: Fabian Hemmert: The shape-shifting future of the mobile phone
item.itunes:summary: At TEDxBerlin, Fabian Hemmert demos one future of the mobile phone -- a shape-shifting and weight-shifting handset that "displays" information nonvisually, offering a delightfully intuitive way to communicate.

item.title: TEDTalks : Annie Lennox: Why I am an HIV/AIDS activist - Annie Lennox (2010)
item.itunes:author: Annie Lennox
item.description: For the last eight years, pop singer Annie Lennox has devoted the majority of her time to her SING campaign, raising awareness and money to combat HIV/AIDS. She shares the experiences that have inspired her, from working with Nelson Mandela to meeting a little African girl in a desperate situation.
item.itunes:subtitle: Annie Lennox: Why I am an HIV/AIDS activist
item.itunes:summary: For the last eight years, pop singer Annie Lennox has devoted the majority of her time to her SING campaign, raising awareness and money to combat HIV/AIDS. She shares the experiences that have inspired her, from working with Nelson Mandela to meeting a little African girl in a desperate situation.

item.title: TEDTalks : Mitchell Besser: Mothers helping mothers fight HIV - Mitchell Besser (2010)
item.itunes:author: Mitchell Besser
item.description: In sub-Saharan Africa, HIV infections are more prevalent and doctors scarcer than anywhere else in the world. With a lack of medical professionals, Mitchell Besser enlisted the help of his patients to create mothers2mothers -- an extraordinary network of HIV-positive women whose support for each other is changing and saving lives.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mitchell Besser: Mothers helping mothers fight HIV

item.title: TEDTalks : Steven Johnson: Where good ideas come from - Steven Johnson (2010)
item.itunes:author: Steven Johnson
item.description: People often credit their ideas to individual "Eureka!" moments. But Steven Johnson shows how history tells a different story. His fascinating tour takes us from the "liquid networks" of London's coffee houses to Charles Darwin's long, slow hunch to today's high-velocity web.

item.itunes:author: Christien Meindertsma
item.description: Christien Meindertsma, author of "Pig 05049" looks at the astonishing afterlife of the ordinary pig, parts of which make their way into at least 185 non-pork products, from bullets to artificial hearts.

item.title: TEDTalks : Caroline Phillips: Hurdy-gurdy for beginners - Caroline Phillips (2010)
item.itunes:author: Caroline Phillips
item.description: Caroline Phillips cranks out tunes on a seldom-heard folk instrument: the hurdy-gurdy, a.k.a. the wheel fiddle. A searching, Basque melody follows her fun lesson on its unique anatomy and 1,000-year history.

item.title: TEDTalks : Nicholas Christakis: How social networks predict epidemics - Nicholas Christakis (2010)
item.itunes:author: Nicholas Christakis
item.description: After mapping humans' intricate social networks, Nicholas Christakis and colleague James Fowler began investigating how this information could better our lives. Now, he reveals his hot-off-the-press findings: These networks can be used to detect epidemics earlier than ever, from the spread of innovative ideas to risky behaviors to viruses (like H1N1).

item.title: TEDTalks : Jessa Gamble: Our natural sleep cycle - Jessa Gamble (2010)
item.itunes:author: Jessa Gamble
item.description: In today's world, balancing school, work, kids and more, most of us can only hope for the recommended eight hours of sleep. Examining the science behind our body's internal clock, Jessa Gamble reveals the surprising and substantial program of rest we should be observing.

item.title: TEDTalks : Chris Anderson: How web video powers global innovation - Chris Anderson (TED) (2010)
item.itunes:author: Chris Anderson (TED)
item.description: TED's Chris Anderson says the rise of web video is driving a worldwide phenomenon he calls Crowd Accelerated Innovation -- a self-fueling cycle of learning that could be as significant as the invention of print. But to tap into its power, organizations will need to embrace radical openness. And for TED, it means the dawn of a whole new chapter ...

item.title: TEDTalks : Rob Dunbar: Discovering ancient climates in oceans and ice - Rob Dunbar (2010)
item.itunes:author: Rob Dunbar
item.description: Rob Dunbar hunts for data on our climate from 12,000 years ago, finding clues inside ancient seabeds and corals and inside ice sheets. His work is vital in setting baselines for fixing our current climate -- and in tracking the rise of deadly ocean acidification.

item.title: TEDTalks : Ben Cameron: The true power of the performing arts - Ben Cameron (2010)
item.itunes:author: Ben Cameron
item.description: Arts administrator and live-theater fan Ben Cameron looks at the state of the live arts -- asking: How can the magic of live theater, live music, live dance compete with the always-on Internet? At TEDxYYC, he offers a bold look forward.

item.title: TEDTalks : Carne Ross: An independent diplomat - Carne Ross (2009)
item.itunes:author: Carne Ross
item.description: After 15 years in the British diplomatic corps, Carne Ross became a "freelance diplomat," running a bold nonprofit that gives small, developing and yet-unrecognized nations a voice in international relations. At the BIF-5 conference, he calls for a new kind of diplomacy that gives voice to small countries, that works with changing boundaries and that welcomes innovation.

item.title: TEDTalks : Alwar Balasubramaniam: Art of substance and absence - Alwar Balasubramaniam (2009)
item.itunes:author: Alwar Balasubramaniam
item.description: Alwar Balasubramaniam's sculpture plays with time, shape, shadow, perspective: four tricky sensations that can reveal -- or conceal -- what's really out there. At TEDIndia, the artist shows slides of his extraordinary installations.

item.title: TEDTalks : Sugata Mitra: The child-driven education - Sugata Mitra (2010)
item.itunes:author: Sugata Mitra
item.description: Education scientist Sugata Mitra tackles one of the greatest problems of education -- the best teachers and schools don't exist where they're needed most. In a series of real-life experiments from New Delhi to South Africa to Italy, he gave kids self-supervised access to the web and saw results that could revolutionize how we think about teaching.

item.title: TEDTalks : Rachel Sussman: The world's oldest living things - Rachel Sussman (2010)
item.itunes:author: Rachel Sussman
item.description: Rachel Sussman shows photographs of the world's oldest continuously living organisms -- from 2,000-year-old brain coral off Tobago's coast to an "underground forest" in South Africa that has lived since before the dawn of agriculture.

item.title: TEDTalks : Derek Sivers: Keep your goals to yourself - Derek Sivers (2010)
item.itunes:author: Derek Sivers
item.description: After hitting on a brilliant new life plan, our first instinct is to tell someone, but Derek Sivers says it's better to keep goals secret. He presents research stretching as far back as the 1920s to show why people who talk about their ambitions may be less likely to achieve them.
item.itunes:subtitle: Derek Sivers: Keep your goals to yourself

item.title: TEDTalks : His Holiness the Karmapa: The technology of the heart - His Holiness the Karmapa (2009)
item.itunes:author: His Holiness the Karmapa
item.description: His Holiness the Karmapa talks about how he was discovered to be the reincarnation of a revered figure in Tibetan Buddhism. In telling his story, he urges us to work on not just technology and design, but the technology and design of the heart. He is translated onstage by Tyler Dewar.

item.title: TEDTalks : Johan Rockstrom: Let the environment guide our development - Johan Rockstrom (2010)
item.itunes:author: Johan Rockstrom
item.description: Human growth has strained the Earth's resources, but as Johan Rockstrom reminds us, our advances also give us the science to recognize this and change behavior. His research has found nine "planetary boundaries" that can guide us in protecting our planet's many overlapping ecosystems.

item.title: TEDTalks : Nic Marks: The Happy Planet Index - Nic Marks (2010)
item.itunes:author: Nic Marks
item.description: Statistician Nic Marks asks why we measure a nation's success by its productivity -- instead of by the happiness and well-being of its people. He introduces the Happy Planet Index, which tracks national well-being against resource use (because a happy life doesn't have to cost the earth). Which countries rank highest in the HPI? You might be surprised.

item.title: TEDTalks : Dan Cobley: What physics taught me about marketing - Dan Cobley (2010)
item.itunes:author: Dan Cobley
item.description: Physics and marketing don't seem to have much in common, but Dan Cobley is passionate about both. He brings these unlikely bedfellows together using Newton's second law, Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, the scientific method and the second law of thermodynamics to explain the fundamental theories of branding.

item.title: TEDTalks : Lisa Margonelli: The political chemistry of oil - Lisa Margonelli (2010)
item.itunes:author: Lisa Margonelli
item.description: In the Gulf oil spill's aftermath, Lisa Margonelli says drilling moratoriums and executive ousters make for good theater, but distract from the issue at its heart: our unrestrained oil consumption. She shares her bold plan to wean America off of oil -- by confronting consumers with its real cost.

item.itunes:author: Jim Toomey
item.description: Cartoonist Jim Toomey created the comic strip Sherman's Lagoon, a wry look at underwater life starring Sherman the talking shark. As he sketches some of his favorite sea creatures live onstage, Toomey shares his love of the ocean and the stories it can tell.

item.itunes:author: Robert Lee Hotz
item.description: Science columnist Lee Hotz describes a remarkable project at WAIS Divide, Antarctica, where a hardy team are drilling into ten-thousand-year-old ice to extract vital data on our changing climate.

item.itunes:author: David McCandless
item.description: David McCandless turns complex data sets (like worldwide military spending, media buzz, Facebook status updates) into beautiful, simple diagrams that tease out unseen patterns and connections. Good design, he suggests, is the best way to navigate information glut -- and it may just change the way we see the world.

item.itunes:author: Sheryl WuDunn

item.itunes:author: Jason Clay
item.description: Convince just 100 key companies to go sustainable, and WWF's Jason Clay says global markets will shift to protect the planet our consumption has already outgrown. item.title: TEDTalks : Lewis Pugh's mind-shifting Everest swim - Lewis Pugh (2010)
item.itunes:author: Lewis Pugh
item.description: After he swam the North Pole, Lewis Pugh vowed never to take another cold-water dip. Then he heard of Lake Imja in the Himalayas, created by recent glacial melting, and Lake Pumori, a body of water at an altitude of 5300 m on Everest -- and so began a journey that would teach him a radical new way to approach swimming and think about climate change.

item.itunes:author: Tan Le

item.title: TEDTalks : Dimitar Sasselov: How we found hundreds of potential Earth-like planets - Dimitar Sasselov (2010)
item.itunes:author: Dimitar Sasselov
item.description: Astronomer Dimitar Sasselov and his colleagues search for Earth-like planets that may, someday, help us answer centuries-old questions about the origin and existence of biological life elsewhere (and on Earth). item.itunes:author: Naif Al-Mutawa

item.title: TEDTalks : Julian Assange: Why the world needs WikiLeaks - Julian Assange (2010)
item.itunes:author: Julian Assange

item.description: Listening to stories widens the imagination; telling them lets us leap over cultural walls, embrace different experiences, feel what others feel. Elif Shafak builds on this simple idea to argue that fiction can overcome identity politics.

item.itunes:author: Ethan Zuckerman
item.description: Sure, the web connects the globe, but most of us end up hearing mainly from people just like ourselves. item.itunes:summary: Sure, the web connects the globe, but most of us end up hearing mainly from people just like ourselves. Blogger and technologist Ethan Zuckerman wants to help share the stories of the whole wide world. He talks about clever strategies to open up your Twitter world and read the news in languages you don't even know.

item.title: TEDTalks : Matt Ridley: When ideas have sex - Matt Ridley (2010)
item.itunes:author: Matt Ridley
item.description: At TEDGlobal 2010, author Matt Ridley shows how, throughout history, the engine of human progress has been the meeting and mating of ideas to make new ideas. It's not important how clever individuals are, he says; what really matters is how smart the collective brain is.
item.itunes:subtitle: Matt Ridley: When ideas have sex
item.itunes:summary: At TEDGlobal 2010, author Matt Ridley shows how, throughout history, the engine of human progress has been the meeting and mating of ideas to make new ideas. It's not important how clever individuals are, he says; what really matters is how smart the collective brain is.

item.title: TEDTalks : Carl Safina: The oil spill's unseen culprits, victims - Carl Safina (2010)
item.itunes:author: Carl Safina
item.description: The Gulf oil spill dwarfs comprehension, but we know this much: it's bad. Carl Safina scrapes out the facts in this blood-boiling cross-examination, arguing that the consequences will stretch far beyond the Gulf -- and many so-called solutions are making the situation worse.
item.itunes:subtitle: Carl Safina: The oil spill's unseen culprits, victims

item.title: TEDTalks : Hans Rosling on global population growth - Hans Rosling (2010)
item.itunes:author: Hans Rosling
item.description: The world's population will grow to 9 billion over the next 50 years -- and only by raising the living standards of the poorest can we check population growth. This is the paradoxical answer that Hans Rosling unveils at TED@Cannes using colorful new data display technology (you'll see).
item.itunes:subtitle: Hans Rosling on global population growth

This is the paradoxical answer that Hans Rosling unveils at TED@Cannes using colorful new data display technology (you'll see).

item.title: TEDTalks : Nalini Nadkarni: Life science in prison - Nalini Nadkarni (2010)
item.itunes:author: Nalini Nadkarni
item.description: Nalini Nadkarni challenges our perspective on trees and prisons -- she says both can be more dynamic than we think. Through a partnership with the state of Washington, she brings science classes and conservation programs to inmates, with unexpected results.
item.itunes:subtitle: Nalini Nadkarni: Life science in prison
item.itunes:summary: Nalini Nadkarni challenges our perspective on trees and prisons -- she says both can be more dynamic than we think. Through a partnership with the state of Washington, she brings science classes and conservation programs to inmates, with unexpected results.

item.title: TEDTalks : Ellen Gustafson: Obesity + Hunger = 1 global food issue - Ellen Gustafson (2010)
item.itunes:author: Ellen Gustafson
item.description: Co-creator of the philanthropic FEED bags, Ellen Gustafson says hunger and obesity are two sides of the same coin. At TEDxEast, she launches The 30 Project -- a way to change how we farm and eat in the next 30 years, and solve the global food inequalities behind both epidemics.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ellen Gustafson: Obesity + Hunger = 1 global food issue
item.itunes:summary: Co-creator of the philanthropic FEED bags, Ellen Gustafson says hunger and obesity are two sides of the same coin. At TEDxEast, she launches The 30 Project -- a way to change how we farm and eat in the next 30 years, and solve the global food inequalities behind both epidemics.

item.title: TEDTalks : Benoit Mandelbrot: Fractals and the art of roughness - Benoit Mandelbrot (2010)
item.itunes:author: Benoit Mandelbrot
item.description: At TED2010, mathematics legend Benoit Mandelbrot develops a theme he first discussed at TED in 1984 -- the extreme complexity of roughness, and the way that fractal math can find order within patterns that seem unknowably complicated.
item.itunes:subtitle: Benoit Mandelbrot: Fractals and the art of roughness
item.itunes:summary: At TED2010, mathematics legend Benoit Mandelbrot develops a theme he first discussed at TED in 1984 -- the extreme complexity of roughness, and the way that fractal math can find order within patterns that seem unknowably complicated.

item.title: TEDTalks : Mitchell Joachim: Don't build your home, grow it! - Mitchell Joachim (2010)
item.itunes:author: Mitchell Joachim
item.description: TED Fellow and urban designer Mitchell Joachim presents his vision for sustainable, organic architecture: eco-friendly abodes grown from plants and -- wait for it -- meat.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mitchell Joachim: Don't build your home, grow it!
item.itunes:summary: TED Fellow and urban designer Mitchell Joachim presents his vision for sustainable, organic architecture: eco-friendly abodes grown from plants and -- wait for it -- meat.

item.title: TEDTalks : Carter Emmart demos a 3D atlas of the universe - Carter Emmart (2010)
item.itunes:author: Carter Emmart
item.description: For the last 12 years, Carter Emmart has been coordinating the efforts of scientists, artists and programmers to build a complete 3D visualization of our known universe. He demos this stunning tour and explains how it's being shared with facilities around the world.
item.itunes:subtitle: Carter Emmart demos a 3D atlas of the universe
item.itunes:summary: For the last 12 years, Carter Emmart has been coordinating the efforts of scientists, artists and programmers to build a complete 3D visualization of our known universe. He demos this stunning tour and explains how it's being shared with facilities around the world.

item.title: TEDTalks : Stephen Palumbi: Following the mercury trail - Stephen Palumbi (2010)
item.itunes:author: Stephen Palumbi
item.description: There's a tight and surprising link between the ocean's health and ours, says marine biologist Stephen Palumbi. He shows how toxins at the bottom of the ocean food chain find their way into our bodies, with a shocking story of toxic contamination from a Japanese fish market. His work points a way forward for saving the oceans' health -- and humanity's.
item.itunes:subtitle: Stephen Palumbi: Following the mercury trail

His work points a way forward for saving the oceans' health -- and humanity's.

item.title: TEDTalks : Ellen Dunham-Jones: Retrofitting suburbia - Ellen Dunham-Jones (2010)
item.itunes:author: Ellen Dunham-Jones
item.description: Ellen Dunham-Jones fires the starting shot for the next 50 years' big sustainable design project: retrofitting suburbia. To come: Dying malls rehabilitated, dead "big box" stores re-inhabited, parking lots transformed into thriving wetlands.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ellen Dunham-Jones: Retrofitting suburbia

item.title: TEDTalks : Clay Shirky: How cognitive surplus will change the world - Clay Shirky (2010)
item.itunes:author: Clay Shirky
item.description: Clay Shirky looks at "cognitive surplus" -- the shared, online work we do with our spare brain cycles. While we're busy editing Wikipedia, posting to Ushahidi (and yes, making LOLcats), we're building a better, more cooperative world.
item.itunes:subtitle: Clay Shirky: How cognitive surplus will change the world
item.itunes:summary: Clay Shirky looks at "cognitive surplus" -- the shared, online work we do with our spare brain cycles. While we're busy editing Wikipedia, posting to Ushahidi (and yes, making LOLcats), we're building a better, more cooperative world.

item.title: TEDTalks : Hillel Cooperman: Legos for grownups - Hillel Cooperman (2010)
item.itunes:author: Hillel Cooperman
item.description: Lego blocks: playtime mainstay for industrious kids, obsession for many (ahem!) mature adults. Hillel Cooperman takes us on a trip through the beloved bricks' colorful, sometimes oddball grownup subculture, featuring CAD, open-source robotics and a little adult behavior.
item.itunes:subtitle: Hillel Cooperman: Legos for grownups

item.title: TEDTalks : Aditi Shankardass: A second opinion on learning disorders - Aditi Shankardass (2009)
item.itunes:author: Aditi Shankardass
item.description: Developmental disorders in children are typically diagnosed by observing behavior, but Aditi Shankardass knew that we should be looking directly at their brains. She explains how a remarkable EEG device has revealed mistaken diagnoses and transformed children's lives.
item.itunes:subtitle: Aditi Shankardass: A second opinion on learning disorders
item.itunes:summary: Developmental disorders in children are typically diagnosed by observing behavior, but Aditi Shankardass knew that we should be looking directly at their brains. She explains how a remarkable EEG device has revealed mistaken diagnoses and transformed children's lives.

item.title: TEDTalks : Charles Leadbeater: Education innovation in the slums - Charles Leadbeater (2010)
item.itunes:author: Charles Leadbeater
item.description: Charles Leadbeater went looking for radical new forms of education -- and found them in the slums of Rio and Kibera, where some of the world's poorest kids are finding transformative new ways to learn. And this informal, disruptive new kind of school, he says, is what all schools need to become.
item.itunes:subtitle: Charles Leadbeater: Education innovation in the slums

And this informal, disruptive new kind of school, he says, is what all schools need to become.

item.title: TEDTalks : Marian Bantjes: Intricate beauty by design - Marian Bantjes (2010)
item.itunes:author: Marian Bantjes
item.description: In graphic design, Marian Bantjes says, throwing your individuality into a project is heresy. She explains how she built her career doing just that, bringing her signature delicate illustrations to storefronts, valentines and even genetic diagrams.
item.itunes:subtitle: Marian Bantjes: Intricate beauty by design
item.itunes:summary: In graphic design, Marian Bantjes says, throwing your individuality into a project is heresy. She explains how she built her career doing just that, bringing her signature delicate illustrations to storefronts, valentines and even genetic diagrams.

item.title: TEDTalks : Chip Conley: Measuring what makes life worthwhile - Chip Conley (2010)
item.itunes:author: Chip Conley
item.description: When the dotcom bubble burst, hotelier Chip Conley went in search of a business model based on happiness. In an old friendship with an employee and in the wisdom of a Buddhist king, he learned that success comes from what you count.
item.itunes:subtitle: Chip Conley: Measuring what makes life worthwhile
item.itunes:summary: When the dotcom bubble burst, hotelier Chip Conley went in search of a business model based on happiness. In an old friendship with an employee and in the wisdom of a Buddhist king, he learned that success comes from what you count.

item.title: TEDTalks : Ananda Shankar Jayant fights cancer with dance - Ananda Shankar Jayant (2009)
item.itunes:author: Ananda Shankar Jayant
item.description: Renowned classical Indian dancer Ananda Shankar Jayant was diagnosed with cancer in 2008. She tells her personal story of not only facing the disease but dancing through it, and gives a performance revealing the metaphor of strength that helped her do it.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ananda Shankar Jayant fights cancer with dance
item.itunes:summary: Renowned classical Indian dancer Ananda Shankar Jayant was diagnosed with cancer in 2008. She tells her personal story of not only facing the disease but dancing through it, and gives a performance revealing the metaphor of strength that helped her do it.

item.title: TEDTalks : Cameron Herold: Let's raise kids to be entrepreneurs - Cameron Herold (2010)
item.itunes:author: Cameron Herold
item.description: Bored in school, failing classes, at odds with peers: This child might be an entrepreneur, says Cameron Herold. At TEDxEdmonton, he makes the case for parenting and education that helps would-be entrepreneurs flourish -- as kids and as adults.
item.itunes:subtitle: Cameron Herold: Let's raise kids to be entrepreneurs
item.itunes:summary: Bored in school, failing classes, at odds with peers: This child might be an entrepreneur, says Cameron Herold. At TEDxEdmonton, he makes the case for parenting and education that helps would-be entrepreneurs flourish -- as kids and as adults.

item.title: TEDTalks : Peter Tyack: The intriguing sound of marine mammals - Peter Tyack (2010)
item.itunes:author: Peter Tyack
item.description: Peter Tyack of Woods Hole talks about a hidden wonder of the sea: underwater sound. Onstage at Mission Blue, he explains the amazing ways whales use sound and song to communicate across hundreds of miles of ocean.
item.itunes:subtitle: Peter Tyack: The intriguing sound of marine mammals
item.itunes:summary: Peter Tyack of Woods Hole talks about a hidden wonder of the sea: underwater sound. Onstage at Mission Blue, he explains the amazing ways whales use sound and song to communicate across hundreds of miles of ocean.

item.title: TEDTalks : Margaret Gould Stewart: How YouTube thinks about copyright - Margaret Gould Stewart (2010)
item.itunes:author: Margaret Gould Stewart
item.description: Margaret Gould Stewart, YouTube's head of user experience, talks about how the ubiquitous video site works with copyright holders and creators to foster (at the best of times) a creative ecosystem where everybody wins.
item.itunes:subtitle: Margaret Gould Stewart: How YouTube thinks about copyright
item.itunes:summary: Margaret Gould Stewart, YouTube's head of user experience, talks about how the ubiquitous video site works with copyright holders and creators to foster (at the best of times) a creative ecosystem where everybody wins.

item.title: TEDTalks : Michael Shermer: The pattern behind self-deception - Michael Shermer (2010)
item.itunes:author: Michael Shermer
item.description: Michael Shermer says the human tendency to believe strange things -- from alien abductions to dowsing rods -- boils down to two of the brain's most basic, hard-wired survival skills. He explains what they are, and how they get us into trouble.
